title: C-ration
data:
**[English]()** • [中文（中国大陆）‎](/wiki/C-ration/zh-CN "C-ration/zh-CN")

| % [![C-ration.png](/images/4/45/C-ration.png)](/wiki/File:C-ration.png) |                                        |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------- | -------------------------------------- |
| Name                                                                    | C-ration                               |
| Base price                                                              | 20 [zm](/wiki/Zorkmid "Zorkmid")       |
| Nutrition                                                               | [300](/wiki/Nutrition "Nutrition")     |
| Turns to eat                                                            | 1                                      |
| Weight                                                                  | [10](/wiki/Weight "Weight")            |
| Conduct                                                                 | [vegan](/wiki/Conduct#Vegan "Conduct") |

The **C-ration** is a type of [comestible](/wiki/Comestible "Comestible") that appears in *[Nethack](/wiki/Nethack "Nethack")*. It is [veggy](/wiki/Veggy "Veggy") and considered [vegan](/wiki/Vegan "Vegan").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Origin](#Origin)

- [6 Messages](#Messages)

- [7 Variants](#Variants)

  - [7.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [7.2 SpliceHack](#SpliceHack)

- [8 References](#References)

## Generation

C-rations are not randomly generated.

[Mercenaries](/wiki/Mercenaries "Mercenaries") that are part of the [Yendorian Army](/wiki/Yendorian_Army "Yendorian Army") have a 1⁄2 chance of [being generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") a C-ration.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

## Description

When [eaten](/wiki/Eaten "Eaten"), C-rations grant 300 [nutrition](/wiki/Nutrition "Nutrition"), and usually take one move to consume similar to [K-rations](/wiki/K-ration "K-ration"). C-rations can [tame](/wiki/Tame "Tame") [domestic](/wiki/Domestic "Domestic") [canines](/wiki/Canine "Canine") and [felines](/wiki/Feline "Feline") and pacify domestic [equines](/wiki/Equine "Equine").

## Strategy

C-rations are a valuable source of quick nutrition in desperate situations, and are plentiful for characters that can clear out [barracks](/wiki/Barracks "Barracks") like those found in [Fort Ludios](/wiki/Fort_Ludios "Fort Ludios") and the [Castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle"). Though K-rations and C-rations are similar in function and heavier than [lembas wafers](/wiki/Lembas_wafer "Lembas wafer"), C-rations are somewhat less preferred due to K-rations having a higher overall nutrition and higher nutrition-per-turn value.

C-rations are prized by [vegan](/wiki/Vegan "Vegan") [spellcasters](/wiki/Spellcaster "Spellcaster") who are not eligible for [hungerless casting](/wiki/Hungerless_casting "Hungerless casting").

## History

The C-ration first appears in [NetHack 2.3e](/wiki/NetHack_2.3e "NetHack 2.3e").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[C-ration](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Search/C-ration "wikipedia:Special:Search/C-ration")***

C-rations are a real-world ration type that was issued to U.S. military soldiers, most notably during [World War II](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II "wikipedia:World War II"). First issued in 1938, C-rations were officially used until 1958, when they were replaced by the effectively identical [Meal, Combat, Individual](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meal,_Combat,_Individual "wikipedia:Meal, Combat, Individual"); many soldiers continued to refer to the MCI as the C-ration until it was replaced in turn by the [Meal, Ready-to-Eat](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meal,_Ready-to-Eat "wikipedia:Meal, Ready-to-Eat") (MRE) in 1981. In addition to offering a greater variety, the MRE also adopted flat packaging, replacing the cumbersome round cans of the C-ration/MCI.

Each C-ration's meal consisted of two cans, a "B" or bread unit and an "M" or meat unit, with a day's rations consisting of three such meals. As the name suggests, the "M" units contained meat, and even the contents of the "B" units were never vegan, unlike C-rations in *NetHack.* They were very simple fare that quickly gained a reputation for being monotonous.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) The *C* in C-ration does not stand for anything, instead serving to classify these pre-made field rations alongside A-rations (cafeteria-style food served on a military base) and B-rations (communal meals prepared by field kitchens).

## Messages

- This C-ration is bland.

  You ate a non-cursed C-ration.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), C-rations can be [upgraded](/wiki/Upgraded "Upgraded") into [cram rations](/wiki/Cram_ration "Cram ration") or [food rations](/wiki/Food_ration "Food ration"). This also applies to [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM").

### SpliceHack

In [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack"), a C-ration can be combined with a food ration at a [furnace](/wiki/Furnace "Furnace") to create a K-ration.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 668](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L668)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) <http://www.usarmymodels.com/ARTICLES/Rations/crations.html>

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")
html:
C-ration

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
English

 • 中文（中国大陆）‎
%
Name C-ration
Base price 20 zm
Nutrition 300
Turns to eat 1
Weight 10
Conduct vegan

The C-ration is a type of comestible that appears in Nethack. It is veggy and considered vegan.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Description
  • 3 Strategy
  • 4 History
  • 5 Origin
  • 6 Messages
  • 7 Variants
    • 7.1 SLASH'EM
    • 7.2 SpliceHack
  • 8 References

Generation

C-rations are not randomly generated.

Mercenaries that are part of the Yendorian Army have a 1⁄2 chance of being generated with a C-ration.[1]

Description

When eaten, C-rations grant 300 nutrition, and usually take one move to consume similar to K-rations. C-rations can tame domestic canines and felines and pacify domestic equines.

Strategy

C-rations are a valuable source of quick nutrition in desperate situations, and are plentiful for characters that can clear out barracks like those found in Fort Ludios and the Castle. Though K-rations and C-rations are similar in function and heavier than lembas wafers, C-rations are somewhat less preferred due to K-rations having a higher overall nutrition and higher nutrition-per-turn value.

C-rations are prized by vegan spellcasters who are not eligible for hungerless casting.

History

The C-ration first appears in NetHack 2.3e.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
C-ration

C-rations are a real-world ration type that was issued to U.S. military soldiers, most notably during World War II. First issued in 1938, C-rations were officially used until 1958, when they were replaced by the effectively identical Meal, Combat, Individual; many soldiers continued to refer to the MCI as the C-ration until it was replaced in turn by the Meal, Ready-to-Eat (MRE) in 1981. In addition to offering a greater variety, the MRE also adopted flat packaging, replacing the cumbersome round cans of the C-ration/MCI.

Each C-ration's meal consisted of two cans, a "B" or bread unit and an "M" or meat unit, with a day's rations consisting of three such meals. As the name suggests, the "M" units contained meat, and even the contents of the "B" units were never vegan, unlike C-rations in NetHack. They were very simple fare that quickly gained a reputation for being monotonous.[2] The C in C-ration does not stand for anything, instead serving to classify these pre-made field rations alongside A-rations (cafeteria-style food served on a military base) and B-rations (communal meals prepared by field kitchens).

Messages

This C-ration is bland.
You ate a non-cursed C-ration.

Variants

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, C-rations can be upgraded into cram rations or food rations. This also applies to SlashTHEM.

SpliceHack

In SpliceHack, a C-ration can be combined with a food ration at a furnace to create a K-ration.

References

  1. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 668
  2. ↑ http://www.usarmymodels.com/ARTICLES/Rations/crations.html

The '''C-ration''' is a type of [[comestible]] that appears in ''[[Nethack]]''. It is [[veggy]] and considered [[vegan]].

==Generation==
C-rations are not randomly generated.

[[Mercenaries]] that are part of the [[Yendorian Army]] have a {{frac|2}} chance of [[monster starting inventory|being generated with]] a C-ration.{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|668|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

==Description==
When [[eaten]], C-rations grant 300 [[nutrition]], and usually take one move to consume similar to [[K-ration]]s. C-rations can [[tame]] [[domestic]] [[canine]]s and [[feline]]s and pacify domestic [[equine]]s.

==Strategy==
C-rations are a valuable source of quick nutrition in desperate situations, and are plentiful for characters that can clear out [[barracks]] like those found in [[Fort Ludios]] and the [[Castle]]. Though K-rations and C-rations are similar in function and heavier than [[lembas wafer]]s, C-rations are somewhat less preferred due to K-rations having a higher overall nutrition and higher nutrition-per-turn value.

C-rations are prized by [[vegan]] [[spellcaster]]s who are not eligible for [[hungerless casting]].

==History==
The C-ration first appears in [[NetHack 2.3e]].

==Origin==
{{wikipedia}}
C-rations are a real-world ration type that was issued to U.S. military soldiers, most notably during [[wikipedia:World War II|World War II]]. First issued in 1938, C-rations were officially used until 1958, when they were replaced by the effectively identical [[Wikipedia:Meal, Combat, Individual|Meal, Combat, Individual]]; many soldiers continued to refer to the MCI as the C-ration until it was replaced in turn by the [[Wikipedia:Meal, Ready-to-Eat|Meal, Ready-to-Eat]] (MRE) in 1981. In addition to offering a greater variety, the MRE also adopted flat packaging, replacing the cumbersome round cans of the C-ration/MCI.

Each C-ration's meal consisted of two cans, a "B" or bread unit and an "M" or meat unit, with a day's rations consisting of three such meals. As the name suggests, the "M" units contained meat, and even the contents of the "B" units were never vegan, unlike C-rations in ''NetHack.''  They were very simple fare that quickly gained a reputation for being monotonous.<ref>http://www.usarmymodels.com/ARTICLES/Rations/crations.html</ref> The ''C'' in C-ration does not stand for anything, instead serving to classify these pre-made field rations alongside A-rations (cafeteria-style food served on a military base) and B-rations (communal meals prepared by field kitchens).

==Messages==
{{message|This C-ration is bland.|You ate a non-cursed C-ration.}}

==Variants==
===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], C-rations can be [[upgraded]] into [[cram ration]]s or [[food ration]]s. This also applies to [[SlashTHEM]].

===SpliceHack===
In [[SpliceHack]], a C-ration can be combined with a food ration at a [[furnace]] to create a K-ration.
